VmVD5Xp9cidrheS0bdo2Ig.text: A craving for Japanese food led my friends and I to Ginza Bairin one fine afternoon. As I felt like having something soup, I went for the spicy tonkotsu ramen. It was really rather spicy which was quite a good twist from usual non-spicy ramen, but the soup base was disappointingly bland. There was a lot of noodles, although there could probably be more ingredients. The service was extremely fast and there wasn't much to complain about. I would go back again probably to try their katsudon which they're more famous for, definitely not for the ramen.

Urn5M7tV87ZF3y8cxHMYdw.text: Ginza Bairin is located at B4 basement at Ion Orchard. I love the Ginza Bairin in Tokyo. The one here is very different in terms of the decor and ambience. The Ginza Bairin is cozy and warmth. I know I know, I kept overusing the word "cozy", but I really really like cozy places. Perhaps the Ginza Bairin Singapore has a bit of a almost fast food feel, or maybe it was just the lightings. Not sure why there were so many white/bright lightings in many places in Singapore; my face looked sickly greenish once in a grocery store. It was hideous!!The staffs here were always nice but the staffs at Ginza Bairin in Tokyo were nice and warmth. Ginza Bairin is famous for tonkatsu which is fried Japanese pork cutlet. The tonkatsu here was always crispy, tender and juicy during my visits there. Ginza Bairin is definitely for people who love tonkatsu!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Ebi Fry Don
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. More Tonkatsu
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Tonkatsu

vA9ZoPlY5v-bZ9syLo6wpA.text: Recently the causal Japanese restaurant has re-opened after been closed for upgrading. The restaurant is known for its deep fried pork cutlet. There is 50% off the items in the menu for the first 3 days. However the well-known sandwiches and side dishes are not available during the promotion period. Although there is a lot of people queuing up for the promotion, one can find a seat easily as food is served quite fast and the turnover is fast too.After making payment at the cashier, one would be given a number tag where food will be served to you at your table.Tonteki (pork steak) ($22)Served with Gonzalez bairin's special sauce, pickles and deep fried garlic slices. Plus a bowl of miso soup. The dish is one of the new dishes in the new menu. The meat is juicy and goes well with the wasabi like sauce. However the garlic slices are not crispy and texture too chewy.Ton Kara ($2.50)Available in 3 types : pork, chicken and chicken wing. Battered with Bairin's way of battering, then cooked with CONFIT cooking method which involves cooking the meat in its own fat.The pork version is too fatty with the thick layers of fat, while the chicken version is too salty. The chicken wing fares slightly better.Overall the food is average with improvements needed. Service is not bad with staffs clearing the tables swiftly.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Tonkara (pork karaage)
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Kara-age (fried chicken)

rHqoW6nRF-8BWYl49HtmfQ.text: Know I was supposed to eat their tonkatsu here but the karaage curry udon called out to me and got that instead. It was $16.00 inclusive of 7% GST, I didn't think it was worth that price for something I could get fast food version in Japan or event at a food court here in Singapore. The tonkatsu costs around $21-25; not worth the price either. The price probably is to cover up rent in ION orchard; but definitely not the quality of the food. Karaage usually comes in small pieces but ginza bairin chose to have them large - too big in my opinion. Had a hard time biting off the chicken to fit my mouth; even tore the roof of my mouth in the process...

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Karaage Curry Udon

sCQgX1GAeFiAF-7YI6hmhA.text: A favorite place for curry rice and tonkatsu. The materials are mostly from Japan and price is reasonable compared to other Tonkatsu stores in Singapore. I always go with Tonkatsu or Curry rice there. Order Kurobuta (black pig) tonkatsu, the meat is more juicy.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Spanish pork tonkatsu
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Tonkatsu
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore

e-czbAZiIShAI6Px7zOmAw.text: Located in basement 4 food court of ION Mall. The set up does not offer the cozy feeling that you normally have in its home country.  Didn't realise I should order first before seating until got a polite (but nothing warm) reminder from the waiter.  The black pig pork curry was quite presentable, with well fried and juicy hamburger and thick and tasty curry.  The portion was just right.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. A closer look of the pork curry set
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Nice presentation of the pork curry set
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Embedded in a basement food court

AAyYoauDuUZI_c1vOOaCUQ.text: This restaurant is nice when you want to have a quick Tonkatsu meal at a descent price.I ordered the Tonkatsu set (the 140g Kurobuta of course hehehe) that came with rice, cabbage and miso soup. The price of my meal with an iced green tea came up to SGD 22 (which is reasonable for a good Tonkatsu in Singapore). Plus don't forget that the set comes with unlimited rice, cabbage and soup. All you have to do is ask a waiter what you would like and he will bring it to your table. That's pretty awesome because I love eating lots of cabbage with sesame dressing together with the Tonkatsu!! :-)Restaurant: It's really just a place where you eat and leave. It's more a "canteen" style restaurant so don't expect a nice, quiet and cozy venue ;)Service: The service is just okay... It's really the minimum but it's fine for this kind of establishment. Basically, all the waiters do is serve your meal and clean your table when you leave. Don't forget that you must order before sitting!! I saw a few people waiting to order until they noticed people sat holding a number... The waiters don't bother telling you how it works unless you ask (which is what I did).Food: The Tonkatsu was nice with a crispy crust and cooked well keeping the juiciness of the pork. I will definitely go back for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Tonkatsu set

X7SbGHRdE-4xenaWQBj5AQ.text: Very well fried Iberian pork Tonkatsu with fresh and crisp cabbage and addictive dipping sauces for both. The Japanese rice was fluffy and provided the necessary carbs for the day. I enjoyed the meal very much!

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Iberian pork Tonkatsu set

04Sf5qocEikUYYMXE2sXSw.text: Yay I'm a fan!I was so psyched when Ginza Bairin first opened (yeah how many of yooz have been coming here for this long huh?) as it was well marketed as one of the big brands for tonkatsu in Japan.I was here within 3 weeks of it opening (okay that's not that fast) and I've been a fan ever since. The pork is (usually) crispy, flavourful, and the portions are pretty decent. It's a wee bit pricy, but I'm usually quite full wen I'm done so I'm not really complaining.The curry's good, not amazing, but I particularly always like the tonkatsu-don with egg. It's a sloppy mess, but damn is it a delicious sloppy mess.It's not the fanciest of places, nor the cheapest of places, but it's a simple no-frills option that I often turn to when I'm stumped on where to eat. And thankfully, it hasn't let me down yet.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore

aG7f6h-U7QicF0gCWfX68A.text: Considering that it's in prime area at ION Orchard, you would expect it to be pricey. Some tradeoffs have been done to keep a cap on price, which result in the place looking more like a canteen than a restaurant. Place was rather empty for a weekday night at 7pm. Slowly but surely the crowds turned up after 8pm.Knowing that pork cutlets were their speciality, I went for the Special Katsudon ($15 after 10% JPassport discount). It came with a runny egg that I gleefully burst and mixed into the rice. Verdict, it was as good and savory as the ones I had in Japan. Definitely worth an occasional visit when I miss authentic Japanese food.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Special Katsudon

FPmT0cu302sxA2hvHSWCeA.text: Fried food. Frieeeeeed foooooood.Love that stuff--the pork is juicy, the breading crisp, the portions generous. They do have a black pig special that is on limited quantities every day, but I think the regular is good enough for you to save your money for dessert elsewhere!

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore

rjp3pnjP1rfDf9GRoRSTBA.text: This restaurant seemed to have the best queue to join if you're in ION on a weekend night looking for Japanese food. We asked the waitress if we had to find a seat before we joined the queue, she said, 'It's okay, we'll find the seats for you, just queue and order first'. So we did. Turns out after we ordered we were given a number tag and had to find our own seats. Not much of a problem though - there were visibly empty seats.The food took some time to come but it was impressive. The crispy batter that is. It was extravagantly crunchy and wrapped the meat well without being oily. The cheese croquette... Sigh, was a disappointment. The crisps was thick and the potato too, which left little room for the cheese inside. It was a sad patronising smear of cheese. For $3+ per croquette, I'd definitely not buy it again.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore

U-sS46CRF215IfJLkvZNVQ.text: Tonkatsu that is perfectly crispy and succulent meat is not one thing you can find easily here in Singapore. Used to be being disappointed at the poor imitations that local stalls offer, I almost gave up hope of ever finding some decent here in Singapore.Luckily, there's Ginza Bairin. Introduced by my girlfriend, I have to say I was sold the first time I tried it. They have a choice of normal or Kurobuta (black pig) to choose from and I went with the normal option. A set meal costs about $18, pretty pricey for something relatively simple, but after my first encounter, I guess you could say the price is worth it. In addition to the tonkatsu, there is a variety of other dishes on offer as well, but if you ask me, I'd say go for the normal tonkatsu. They definitely won't disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore

b5IfPRtQc-Jfnt2NwpnD6w.text: Located at the basement of Ion Orchard beside the food kiosks, Ginza Bairin doesn't really scream out to you, and if you're not looking for it, its relatively easy to pass it as just another Mos Burger or Japanese fast food joint. While I'm not particularly a big fan of tonkatsu, I have to say that Ginza Bairin does satisfy my cravings with the more than decent offering. The tonkatsu is not too oily and deep fried while retaining the succulent and juicy meat and you always get a good crunch. The variety on offer is really comprehensive so it is always good to take a look at the menu before ordering or you'll definitely hold up the queue.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore

FfjxUGOEl9bW2_TVyYIboA.text: OK I confess, I've been here 4 times, and every time, I order the SAME thing. I'm not sure what it is about this place that keeps me coming back. Perhaps it's the fact that there never seems to be a queue, it's open quite late (I go at around 9pm on weekdays) and the food is quite delicious.  The only issue I have with it is that it's somewhat on the pricey side so I always have to debate if I want to spend close to $20 on a fast-food type meal. I spend around $17 per meal when I get the Croquette Curry Cheese set and an iced green tea. The Croquette Curry Cheese set... mmmm... yummy, though I suspect not very Japanese fare of fried potato / cheese and curry with rice and soup. Being the carb lover that I am, what's not to love??My friend is in love with their Ebi Fry set - she has also ordered this many, many times and it costs around $18. According to her, it's delicious, so that may be worth trying out also. I'll definitely head back here to sample their other dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Potato croquette curry, my favourite dish

H9_GwLlfZI6sXZ4-Ja4nXA.text: I had a discount voucher from Perx and decided to use it for my dinner. at 8:30pm the line at Ginza Bairin was long and even though the place was fully packed, people just kept coming. since it was crowded and i was on my own, i asked for take away. to my dismay, no ramen on the to go menu. sadness so i ordered the unagi don (i forgot the actual name of the dish) - eel and egg on rice. it didn't help when the lady got my order wrong. the kitchen staff came out to clarify and she still got it wrong. it took her about 2 customers later to clarify with me then she asked me to pay the difference in price for the wrong order she put in - by this time i had already waited 10 mins. thank goodness the rice was tasty even though it was like 45 mins later that i got to eat. next time i would choose a better time to eat there.

yprpSwtfPlq4sgKTQxwp_Q.text: Was surprised to see this famous Japanese chain in orchard ion. I made it a point to try the Katsu which I had in Tokyo and the taste was really similar. No frills and tasty Katsu was what drew me to their chain in Tokyo and this new outlet in Singapore did not disappoint. Great place to have Fried breaded Japanese style pork

photos.caption: Photo of Ginza Bairin - Singapore, Singapore. Great tasting pork Katsu

IJ_pz0V41DwJncjdi5oPdw.text: The best tonkatsu in Singapore. Quality is consistent and always impressive. It is priced right and service is very good. It's a eat-in space but staff are nice and responsive, which are not commonly seen. They have variety of dishes. They are good at tobkatsu and i stick with it.

YVjNk7UJgZ7iiiNP7CeWAw.text: Ginza Barin was my frequent choice for dinner after work because the portions are big and the food is pretty decent. The tonkatsu has always been pretty much up to standard - the deep fried breaded pork fillets are not too oily and the meat is usually still tender enough. Recently, I took to the Ebi Fry set -3 huge battered (but succulent) prawns served up with steaming rice accompanied by delicious tartar sauce. But, I won't be going back anytime soon because I had a horrible experience  the last time around. Got berated by a service staff when I requested for a second serving of tartar sauce - apparently it is only ethical to put up this request after you have licked up every last bit of the sauce that is on your plate. Wow. I was flabbergasted considering I had about two dips worth of sauce left. Left a horrible aftertaste so don't patronise this place if you are one who enjoys your food and would like a little more sauce from time to time.

Uav_QR7zWTeQl_yeZQc-RQ.text: Very good!! Always crisp and tasty katsu. Their fried oyster and cheese stuffed pork katsu are both extras I must always order. Another big plus is they open pretty late.

I5jK1VRQ1tA9HlZt9cMu1A.text: I'm deducting a point for refusing to take my order at 9:50pm when their website says they close at 10:30, and for refusing to serve tap water.
